intro: Kuhnia albicaulis, commonly known as the white-stemmed sedge, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the wetlands and marshes of eastern North America. It typically grows in dense colonies, reaching heights of up to 60 cm, with slender, cylindrical stems that are often covered in a white or pale bloom. The plant produces small, inconspicuous greenish flowers in spike-like clusters during the summer months. Its leaves are narrow, linear, and often have a waxy coating, which helps reduce water loss in its moist habitat. Kuhnia albicaulis plays an important ecological role by providing habitat and food for various aquatic and terrestrial organisms.
